content: 1°19′35″N 103°48′12.3″E﻿ / ﻿1.32639°N 103.803417°E﻿ / 1.32639; 103.803417 Historic site in Bukit Timah Road Singapore **The Chinese High School Clock Tower Building**, a gazetted national monument in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), is situated in the campus of the integrated [Hwa Chong Institution](/wiki/Hwa_Chong_Institution), which incorporates [The Chinese High School](/wiki/The_Chinese_High_School) and [Hwa Chong Junior College](/wiki/Hwa_Chong_Junior_College). Standing at 31 metres tall atop a small [knoll](/wiki/Hillock) on which parts of the campus was built on, the building was completed as part of the campus of [The Chinese High School](/wiki/The_Chinese_High_School_(Singapore)) in 1925, funded by generous donations from the Chinese community leaders. It served as an imposing landmark for the [Bukit Timah](/wiki/Bukit_Timah) area where it is surrounded by relatively low-rise private housing estates. It was used in [tactical military](/wiki/Military_tactics) situations during the [Pacific War](/wiki/Pacific_War) in [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II). Its strategic location atop a hill gave any troops stationed in it a good view of the island. It was used by the [Allied](/wiki/ABDACOM) defenders during the [Battle of Singapore](/wiki/Battle_of_Singapore), as well as during the [Japanese Occupation of Singapore](/wiki/Japanese_Occupation_of_Singapore), it was occupied by the [Imperial Japanese Army](/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Army) for the purpose of surveillance. The tower's four-faced clock was destroyed and removed during World War II, and was restored in the early 1970s, with replacements donated by [Seiko](/wiki/Seiko). The clock tower went through a series of restoration and expansion in the 1990s, in which a new library was added. On 19 March 1999, two days before the 80th anniversary of the school, the clock tower was gazetted as a [national monument](/wiki/National_Monuments_of_Singapore), to mark the significance of the institution as the first Chinese-medium [secondary school](/wiki/Secondary_school) to be built in [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia) catering to the [Overseas Chinese](/wiki/Overseas_Chinese) by its founder, Mr [Tan Kah Kee](/wiki/Tan_Kah_Kee). ## Architecture & Facilities The Clock Tower Building is a work by [Swan & Maclaren](/wiki/Swan_and_Maclaren), a renowned firm that also designed the [Sultan Mosque](/wiki/Masjid_Sultan), the [Former Tanjong Pagar Railway Station](/wiki/Tanjong_Pagar_railway_station), [Civilian War Memorial](/wiki/Civilian_War_Memorial), and [Raffles Hotel](/wiki/Raffles_Hotel_Singapore). Neoclassical architectural elements, including a symmetrical plan, the frontal triangular pediment, stately Ionic columns, and arched doorways and windows form distinctive traits of the iconic building. The 36-metre-high clock tower and a cupola, supported by eight small Ionic columns, crowns the tower. The Clock Tower building features eight high roof classrooms catering to the high school section of the institution, previously reserved for the top performing classes. Currently, it serve as venues for students in academic special programmes. ## Gallery
